name: Kepler-390
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-390 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-390 is a star with 0.675 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.78 times its radius. It is located 1437.66 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-390 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-390 b

Kepler-390 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 6.74 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-390.

The mass of Kepler-390 b is 0.59 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-390 b is 0.82 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-390 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-390 c

Kepler-390 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.06 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-390.

The mass of Kepler-390 c is 0.54 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-390 c is 0.79 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-390 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-390, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
